identificationModule.briefTitle: Dry Needling for Shoulder Pain in Stroke Patients
identificationModule.officialTitle: Dry Needling for Shoulder Pain and Presence of Post-needling Induced-Pain in PAtients Who Had Suffered a Stroke

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Spasticity and pain, particularly int he shoulder region, are the most common impairments experienced by subjects who had experienced a stroke. There is preliminary evidence supporting the role of dry needling for spasticity in patients who had suffered from a stroke. Few data exists on the effects on shoulder pain. In addition, it has been shown that application of dry needling induces post-needling soreness in individuals with musculoskeletal pain. No previous study has investigated the presence and the duration of post-needling soreness in individuals who had experienced a stroke.

armGroups.label: Dry needling
armGroups.description: The experimental group will receive a single session of modulatory interventions combined with a single session of dry needling into the shoulder muscles which active trigger points will reproduce the shoulder pain symptoms.

armGroups.label: Physical Therapy
armGroups.description: This group will receive a single session of modulatory interventions targeting modulation of central nervous system.

interventions.name: Dry Needling
interventions.description: A single session of modulatory interventions combined with a single session of dry needling into the shoulder muscles which active trigger points will reproduce the shoulder pain symptoms.

interventions.name: Physical Therapy
interventions.description: A single session of modulatory interventions targeting modulation of central nervous system.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in post-dry needling pain intensity with a numerical pain rate scale before and after the intervention
primaryOutcomes.description: A Numerical Pain Rate Scale (NPRS, 0-10) will be used to record post-dry needling soreness in the targeted area
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 24 hours (1 day) after and 72 hours (3 days) after treatment the intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in spontaneous shoulder pain with a numerical pain rate scale before and after the intervention
secondaryOutcomes.description: A Numerical Pain Rate Scale (NPRS, 0-10) will be used to assess spontaneous shoulder pain
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 72 hours (3 days) and 168 hours (7 days) after treatment the intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Presence of active trigger points in the shoulder musculature
secondaryOutcomes.description: Manual palpation of active trigger points in the shoulder muscles will be conducted
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 72 hours (3 days) and 168 hours (7 days) after treatment the intervention
